item.title: Trump Pardons Klecko, Jamal Lewis and Other Former N.F.L. Players
item.description: The players included Super Bowl champions and a Hall of Famer who had been charged for crimes ranging from perjury to drug trafficking.
item.dc:creator: Adam Sella

item.title: U.S. Aircraft Carrier Will Be Sent to the Middle East From Venezuela, Officials Say
item.description: The U.S.S. Gerald R. Ford is not expected to return until late April or early May.
item.dc:creator: John Ismay and Eric Schmitt
item.media:credit: US Navy/Seaman Apprentice Nathan Sears
item.media:description: Aircraft carrier U.S.S. Gerald R. Ford in the Caribbean Sea last month.

item.title: How The Times Is Digging Into Millions of Pages of Epstein Files
item.description: Two dozen journalists. A pile of pages that would reach the top of the Empire State Building. And an effort to find the next revelation in a sprawling case.
item.dc:creator: Patrick Healy, Steve Eder, Andrew Chavez, Kirsten Danis and Dylan Freedman
item.media:credit: U.S. Department of Justice
item.media:description: A photo of Jeffrey Epstein with other faces redacted by the Justice Department.

item.title: Closing of El Paso Airspace Adds to Tension Between F.A.A. and Pentagon
item.description: The Federal Aviation Administration is charged with flight safety, and the Defense Department with national security. Those missions keep colliding.
item.dc:creator: Kate Kelly, Karoun Demirjian and Eric Schmitt
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:credit: Jose Luis Gonzalez/Reuters
item.media:description: A passenger carried his suitcase at El Paso International Airport after the F.A.A. lifted its temporary closure of the airspace over El Paso.

item.title: Federal Judge Blocks Trump Plan to Cut $600 Million in Health Funds
item.description: It is the latest court ruling staving off deep cuts to social services that Democratic-led states say are politically motivated and would harm hundreds of thousands of people.
item.dc:creator: Chris Cameron
item.media:credit: Dustin Chambers for The New York Times
item.media:description: The $600 million in cuts planned this month include grants to state and local public health departments. The funds are administered through the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention.

item.title: Partial Federal Shutdown Shrinks Congressional Presence in Munich
item.description: In a moment of frayed trans-Atlantic relations, Speaker Mike Johnson abruptly canceled the House delegation to Europe’s biggest annual security summit.
item.dc:creator: Megan Mineiro
item.media:credit: Thomas Kienzle/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Speaker Mike Johnson abruptly canceled the House delegation to the Munich Security Conference.

item.title: The Epstein Files and the Hidden World of an Unaccountable Elite
item.description: The search continues in the documents for ironclad criminal conduct, but the story of a sexual predator given a free ride by the ruling class has already emerged.
item.dc:creator: Robert Draper
item.media:credit: Jon Elswick/Associated Press
item.media:description: Redacted documents showing email chains from Jeffrey Epstein released by the Justice Department.

item.title: 5 Takeaways After Trump’s Immigration Crackdown in Minnesota
item.description: Some 3,000 agents took part in the federal operation that started late last year around the Twin Cities. On Thursday, officials said the surge would wind down.
item.dc:creator: Julie Bosman
item.media:credit: David Guttenfelder/The New York Times
item.media:description: A scene from January in Minnesota, where agents arrested a man.

item.title: C.I.A. Video Appeals to Potential Spies in China’s Military
item.description: The agency is seeking Chinese officials who are frustrated with corruption in the People’s Liberation Army.
item.dc:creator: Julian E. Barnes
item.media:credit: Hector Retamal/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Members of the People’s Liberation Army attending a ceremony in December. Corruption in China’s military has hampered its push to modernize and improve capabilities.

item.title: The High-Stakes Fight Over Masked Federal Agents
item.description: The debate over whether federal agents should be allowed to cover their faces with masks has become a flashpoint as the government heads for a partial shutdown.
item.dc:creator: Luke Broadwater
item.media:credit: David Guttenfelder/The New York Times
item.media:description: A masked Customs and Border Protection agent during an arrest in Minneapolis last month.

item.title: Karrin Taylor Robson Ends Bid for Arizona Governor, Showing MAGA’s Power
item.description: Karrin Taylor Robson, a wealthy businesswoman, dropped out after trailing in polls to Representative Andy Biggs, who is more aligned with supporters of President Trump.
item.dc:creator: Kellen Browning
item.media:credit: Caitlin O'Hara for The New York Times
item.media:description: Karrin Taylor Robson had earned President Trump’s early endorsement, but he later also bestowed his support to Representative Andy Biggs, a member of the hard-line Freedom Caucus.

item.title: The DHS Shutdown Could Affect ICE, Travelers, FEMA and More
item.description: A lapse in funding probably won’t bring immigration enforcement operations to a screeching halt, but the department is also home to other agencies, including the Coast Guard and FEMA.
item.dc:creator: Karoun Demirjian and Madeleine Ngo
item.media:credit: Jason Henry for The New York Times
item.media:description: About 95 percent of T.S.A.’s employees are expected to report to work through a shutdown without pay.

item.title: Intelligence Dispute Centers on Kushner Reference in Intercepted Communication
item.description: A whistle-blower has accused Tulsi Gabbard, the director of national intelligence, of blocking distribution of a report that Jared Kushner’s name came up in an intercepted communication about Iran.
item.dc:creator: Julian E. Barnes and Tyler Pager
item.category: Office of the Director of National Intelligence
item.media:credit: Nathan Howard for The New York Times
item.media:description: Jared Kushner during a briefing at the Civil-Military Coordination Center in southern Israel in October, while on a trip with Vice President JD Vance.

item.title: U.S. Forces Leave Base in Syria Used in Fight Against ISIS
item.description: The military base at Al-Tanf had hosted U.S. troops fighting against the Islamic State since 2016. Some of the troops are expected to be repositioned at a Jordanian military base across the border.
item.dc:creator: John Ismay
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.media:credit: Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: American troops in Syria in 2019.

item.title: Judge Says Trump Administration Must Help Return Venezuelans Deported to El Salvador
item.description: The ruling was one of the most robust steps taken so far to force the Trump administration to give due process to the Venezuelan immigrants deported under the Alien Enemies Act.
item.dc:creator: Alan Feuer
item.media:credit: Fred Ramos for The New York Times
item.media:description: The ruling followed a decision issued in December that found the immigrants had been denied due process when they were flown to El Salvador, where they spent months in a notorious prison built for terrorists (pictured above).

item.title: Trump’s Actions Test the Fragile World of Air Travel
item.description: Last-minute announcements and abrupt changes by the Trump administration have caused confusion in an already strained U.S. aviation system.
item.dc:creator: Niraj Chokshi and Christine Chung
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:credit: Paul Ratje for The New York Times
item.media:description: A nearly deserted security checkpoint at El Paso International Airport on Wednesday after the Federal Aviation Administration announced a 10-day ban on flights over the city.

item.title: DHS Shutdown Nears as Immigration Enforcement Talks Stall
item.description: Senate Democrats refused to move ahead with a spending bill needed to keep the Department of Homeland Security running because it lacked limits they have demanded on federal immigration agents.
item.dc:creator: Michael Gold and Carl Hulse
item.media:credit: David Guttenfelder/The New York Times
item.media:description: Federal agents confronting protesters in Minneapolis last month.

item.title: Bar Punts on Ethics Complaint Over Application to Search Reporter’s Home
item.description: A press freedom group accused a prosecutor of violating an ethics rule by not telling a judge about a law limiting searches for journalistic work product.
item.dc:creator: Charlie Savage
item.media:credit: Tierney L. Cross/The New York Times
item.media:description: F.B.I. agents searched the home of a Washington Post reporter as part of a criminal investigation into a government contractor accused of leaking classified information to her.

item.title: Minnesota leaders praise residents for standing up to ‘bullies’ during Trump crackdown.
item.dc:creator: Sonia A. Rao
item.media:credit: Jamie Kelter Davis for The New York Times
item.media:description: Residents of Minneapolis using their phones to record federal agents last week.

item.title: Crypto Super PAC Targets Al Green, a Texas Democrat Who Voiced Concerns
item.description: A crypto-backed super PAC plans to spend $1.5 million against Mr. Green, a member of the House Financial Services Committee who has expressed concerns about cryptocurrency.
item.dc:creator: Theodore Schleifer and Shane Goldmacher
item.media:credit: Eric Lee for The New York Times
item.media:description: Representative Al Green of Texas, whose Houston-area district was upended by redistricting, is running against Representative Christian Menefee, a fellow Democrat who won a special election late last month.

item.title: The Republican Party’s Advantage on Immigration Shrinks, Poll Finds
item.description: The new poll from The Associated Press and the NORC Center for Public Affairs Research found the G.O.P. edge on the issue, once in the double digits, had dropped to 4 percent.
item.dc:creator: Ruth Igielnik
item.media:credit: Victor J. Blue for The New York Times
item.media:description: Thousands of demonstrators poured into central Minneapolis in January to protest the actions in the area.

item.title: Americans Are Paying the Bill for Tariffs, Despite Trump’s Claims
item.description: Research from the New York Fed confirms that U.S. companies and consumers are bearing tariff costs, despite the president’s assertions otherwise.
item.dc:creator: Ana Swanson and Sydney Ember
item.category: Bank of New York Mellon Corporation
Federal Reserve Bank of New York
item.media:credit: Mark Abramson for The New York Times
item.media:description: U.S. companies and consumers are paying most of the cost of tariffs, in the form of higher prices.

item.title: Anthropic Donates $20 Million to Super PAC Operation to Counter OpenAI
item.description: Anthropic and OpenAI now have their own well-funded political groups that will square off in the midterm elections over artificial intelligence safety and regulation.
item.dc:creator: Theodore Schleifer
item.media:credit: Karsten Moran for The New York Times
item.media:description: Dario Amodei, a co-founder and chief executive of Anthropic, formerly worked at OpenAI.

item.title: Senators Press Immigration Officials on Minnesota Shootings
item.description: Rand Paul, a Republican, criticized Trump administration officials for labeling Alex Pretti a domestic terrorist ahead of an investigation into his killing.
item.dc:creator: Madeleine Ngo and Michael Gold
item.media:credit: Eric Lee for The New York Times
item.media:description: Todd Lyons, acting director of U.S. Immigration and Customs Enforcement, center, testifying with Joseph Edlow and Rodney S. Scott before the Senate Committee on Homeland Security and Governmental Affairs on Thursday.

item.title: Trump’s Director of Election Security Is an Election Denier
item.description: Even in a government full of conspiracists, Kurt Olsen stands out. He made a key referral in the Fulton County, Ga., election case.
item.dc:creator: Shawn McCreesh, Alexandra Berzon and Nick Corasaniti
item.media:credit: Joe Rondone/The Republic, via USA Today Network
item.media:description: President Trump has installed proponents of his fraud claims all across his administration, including Kurt Olsen, shown here in 2022.

item.title: Ford Will Make a Play for a Different Battery Market
item.description: The company, long focused on cars and trucks, plans to begin manufacturing large batteries used by utilities, data centers, other businesses and homeowners.
item.dc:creator: Jack Ewing
item.media:credit: Jon Cherry for The New York Times
item.media:description: Ford’s closed battery plant in Glendale, Ky., which it plans to revamp to produce large storage batteries.

item.title: Why Pennsylvania’s Two Most Powerful Democrats Don’t Speak
item.description: Senator John Fetterman and Gov. Josh Shapiro do not get along. The bad blood goes back years.
item.dc:creator: Lisa Lerer and Katie Glueck
item.media:credit: Eric Lee for The New York Times, Greg Kahn for The New York Times
item.media:description: Senator John Fetterman and Gov. Josh Shapiro were both rising Democratic stars when they won their offices in 2022. Since then, their political trajectories have diverged.

item.title: Laid-Off Battery Plant Workers Pin Blame on Ford, not Trump, for Lost Jobs
item.description: Ford Motor shut down a battery factory and laid off 1,600 workers after President Trump and Republicans gutted government support for electric vehicles.
item.dc:creator: Jack Ewing
item.media:credit: Jon Cherry for The New York Times
